# 1. invoke lambda function in CLI----      aws lambda invoke --function-name count --payload '{}' output.txt
aws lambda invoke --function-name count \
--payload file://input.txt outputfile.txt --cli-binary-format raw-in-base64-out


#2. To invoke the Lambda function using curl in CLI------   curl https://0z47kyze8e.execute-api.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/prod/count

curl https://444s1go2e2.execute-api.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/prod/count \
-d '{"operation": "create", "payload": {"Item": {"id": "5678EFGH", "count": 15}}}'

#3.To retrieve the secret access key generated by Terraform, you can use the terraform output command. Here are the steps:

Make sure you are in the same directory where your Terraform configuration files are located.
Run the command terraform output secret_access_key in your terminal or command prompt.

#4. To access error logs for an AWS Lambda function named "count," you can use the following command in the AWS Command Line Interface (CLI):

aws logs filter-log-events --log-group-name /aws/lambda/count --filter-pattern "ERROR"

#5 To find out if a DynamoDB table already exists using the AWS CLI, you can use the aws dynamodb describe-table command. Here's an example command:

aws dynamodb describe-table --table-name visitor_count
